description.narrative: TheTanzanian market is replete with chemically-basedskin care products and cosmeticsthatareharmful to peoples health. Hellen is providing an eco-friendly, economic alternative in Zanzibar, where she is manufacturing and selling natural, affordable products and employing low income women. ,

mailing-address.narrative: 1400 I St. NW Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20005

description.narrative: Sector: Agricutlure. Coffee Production and Processing..Beneficiaries: 988 small holder farmers, of which 298 are women. .The expansion grant to Masama Mula AMCOS Ltd will assist the coffee cooperative society to acquire a new coffee pulping unit to replace the current one that is 56 years old. The USADF grant will also improve the irrigation water system leading to increased coffee yields that were previously adversely affected by dry spells. The grant will create an inputs revolving fund that will complement available limited credit services offered by the AMCOS members Savings and Credit Cooperative Society (SACCOS). Grant funds will meet the technical support needed to enhance better agricultural practices and adoption of new coffee varieties for improved coffee production. The expected immediate impacts will include improved coffee processing which will lead to lower processing costs and improved coffee prices. In the medium and long term members will increase coffee yields by adopting new varieties and better farming practices,

description.narrative: Azimio is an expansion rice value chain project that has successfully implemented an USADF supported capacity building project. The expansion project is expected to benefit more than 800 smallholder rice farmers at the Azimio Mswiswi irrigation scheme. Through continued USADF grant and technical support the project seeks to complete the on-going construction of its own warehouse and offices on a newly acquired piece of land in Azimio Mswiswi Village. The group also needs to improve the quality of rice they process so as to remain a competitive rice processor and supplier. The group will need a delivery track to ensure members paddy once harvested is delivered to the milling plant in real time so as to minimize post harvest losses.

description.narrative: The USADF grant of $92,044 being sought by Laela AMCOS will enhance the capacity of the AMCOS to improve the financial and agricultural practices and capacity of the members to increase maize production productivity as well as secure assured markets for farmers maize. Through technical assistance, the capacity of the farmers and the AMCOS as their will be the focal point for economic emancipation will be enhanced to have a strong bargaining position and competitiveness in the maize business..A total of more than 200 AMCOS members and beneficiaries associated with the AMCOS will be impacted through better farming prices, post harvest handling of maize produce to minimize losses and more importantly will have an assured market for their maize produce at pre-agreed and competitive prices. Through their collective effort the farmers will have a stronger voice while negotiating with buyers as a well as dialogue with government for a conducive business environment. On their part, the AMCOS members will contribute and enhance their skills in maize farming on their more than 3,000 acres of land they own (individual plots that add up to 3,025 acres). They will also adopt better skills in maize production and productivity while minimizing post harvest losses.

title.narrative: Improving Food Production and Marketing of High Quality and Safe Maize

description.narrative: Matembwe AMCOS is primarily a maize growing smallholder farmers' cooperative. The AMCOS being rural and remote is comprised of 685 members of which 347 are mainly women and female youths. These are the main direct beneficiaries although indirectly more people in the households indirectly depend on the AMCOS for livelihoods and employment. The objective of the AMCOS is to increase members incomes and livelihoods through increased maize production, productivity and quality. This will be realized with USADF capacity assistance and technical support to use appropriate fertilizers for farms that will be tested for deficiencies. Also the AMCOS will earn additional income from the carbon market using its 523 acres of forest reserves.

title.narrative: Kingerikiti Agricultural Marketing Cooperative Society Limited

description.narrative: Smallholder coffee farming in Mbinga and Nyasa districts in the southern highlands in Tanzania dates back to the colonial days. The close to a century of coffee economy has had its challanges ranging from fluctuating coffee prices, changes in the cooperative policy and emergence of better yielding agricultural crops that have over time out competed coffee. However, the Kingerekiti farmers have remained resilient and still embrace their coffee as an important source of income, price flatuations not withstanding. Coffee has assured farmers of income through the season and into the next season as farmers get advance payments on delivery and subsequent payments as the coffee gets auctioned. It is this spread in earnings that has made farmers continue to grow coffee. However, as observed, coffee industry suffers from quality and quantity issues. The governance of farmer cooperatives has remained a nagging problem. Financial management and control of farmers money has also been a borne of contention. These are all capacity issues which may be addressed by USADF organizational assistance grant to Kingerekiti AMCOS. , The project will directly benefit 320 active cooperative members who sell their coffee through the primary cooperative society. In addition, it is assumed at least 4 members in each of the households of the 320 members depends on income from coffee. These are 1,280 beneficiaries per every year of USADF support to the AMCOS. As coffee production increases through the envisaged interventions, more employment is expected on the farms, among the input suppliers, at processing facilities

mailing-address.narrative: 1400 I St. NW Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20005

description.narrative: We aim at up scaling our production by capitalizing on the use of modern chicken rearing techniques and tools. This will specifically include the use of modern cages, sourcing quality day old chicks, use of better feeds, better bio- security, better management and use the availability of nutritious raw materials such as Soya, amino acids, vitamins, phosphates, enzymes and better farming techniques. The expansion of egg production will ensure availability of nutritious food together with the manure to the community in Arusha and provide employment to the youth who are currently faced with unemployment.

description.narrative: Every year, over 100 million avocados are being underutilized in northern Tanzania, going to waste or being fed to livestock. The avocados short shelf-life makes them largely unsuitable for export, even to nearby local markets. Yesse is capturing value from the avocados by processing them into a higher value product with a better shelf-life; avocado oil. In doing so, raising the standard of living and reducing post-harvest losses for smallholder avocado farmers.

description.narrative: Sector: Agriculture. Export Crop - Coffee Beneficiaries: 910 small holder coffee farmers, of which 250 are women Project Description: The capacity building grant will assist Mwika Kinyamvuo Agriculture and Marketing Cooperative Society to plant improved higher yielding coffee varieties and earn increased incomes. The grant will assist the farmers to form a more organized Value Chain for production, processing and marketing of organic coffee through training in agronomic skills, financial management skills so that they are able to control their financial transactions so as to enhance transparency and accountability. The farmers will use the grant to access training in governance to ensure members are empowered to understand and know their role as key stakeholders of the cooperative. At processing level, the grant will assist the cooperative to complete the installation of new coffee processing equipment. The grant will assist farmers to develop a business plan have access to crop finance so that they receive advance cash payments upon delivery of their coffee to the cooperative.

This will save travelers and bus companies both time and money.

title.narrative: Manushi Sinde Coffee Capacity Building Project

description.narrative: Sector: Agriculture, Beneficiaries: 350 small holder farmers, of which 103 are women., , The Project Description:, This is an agriculture project located in rural Tanzania on the slopes of Mt Kilimanjaro. This is the leading mild arabica coffee producing region in Tanzania but yet suffers from abject poverty that could be avoided and eliminated completely. This calls for more technical support to the organization, use the available resources more optimally and improve the governance set up. The project entails extending an organizational assistance grant to enhance the capacity of the project to grow better varieties of coffee, improve coffee quality, ensure timely procurement of agri-inputs, ensure timely payment for farmers coffee upon delivery at the cooperative and ensure improved governance and financial management and control. The expected outcomes include higher incomes for better quality coffee, improved productivity to ensure more quality coffee is produced form the same area under cultivation. The project will also entail embracing other cross-cutting issues including environmental conservation, HIV aids awareness and alcohol abuse.

description.narrative: Sector: Solar.Summary: LEMS is installing a solar mini-grid in Hanang District, Manyara Region and training mostly women in the use of off-grid solar/wind generated power. The expected impact is increased incomes for women as a result of using the power generated and connected to their business premises as well as usage of power to facilitate preservation of milk and vegetables so as to increase access to markets.

title.narrative: African Women Entrepreneurship Program - Reminaged (AWEP-R): Hatua Project-Phase II

description.narrative: Vikapu Bomba Hatua Project entails the expansion of basket weaving business that will directly engage more than 500 rural women in Iringa Region. With a captive internal and external market, the project will generate gainful employment for 500 rural women, increase basket production to 7,500 units annually and increase in income to the rural women from $30 t0 $180 per month. Overall, the project will directly and indirectly impact more than 2,000 beneficiaries.

mailing-address.narrative: 1400 I St. NW Suite 1000, Washington, DC 20005

description.narrative: Sector: Maize.Beneficiaries: 167 smallholder farmers.Kanyele AMCOS is a resilient and remote farmer organization whose purpose is to develop a strong and growing maize value chain to increase members incomes and build stronger and sustainable rural community in Rukwa Region, Kalambo District 1,500km from Dar es Salaam. The organization has within 4 years grown its membership from 30 to 212 currently and growing. They have managed to bulk together 480MT and successfully supplied to the National Food Reserve Agency between 2015 and 2016. The organization has experienced fluctuating maize prices, a situation that has impacted negatively on farmers incomes. Now the organization has entered into a contract with Mbasira Food Industries Ltd, a Sumbawanga based bulk buyer and processor of maize to supply 600MT during the current season to commence in June 2018. The order guarantees the organization a premium price of Tzs 10/kg above the prevailing market price at the time of supply. This supply arrangement calls for enhancing the AMCOS organizational, financial and agricultural capacities through USADF OAG. Members will need more training in good agricultural practices, post harvest handling of maize through appropriate storage to mimize losses as well as having in place an inputs revolving fund to ensure timely availability of inputs. A technical team to facilitate and capacitate the organization to fulfill its supply obligations would be recommended recourse.
